verses.verse: "Do you know<WH3045> the time<WH6256> when the mountain<WH5553> goats<WH3277> give birth?<WH3205> Do you watch<WH8104> when the doe<WH355> bears fawns?<WH2342>
Can you number<WH5608> the months<WH3391> that they fulfill?<WH4390> Or do<WH4390> you know<WH3045> the time when they give birth?<WH6256>
They bow<WH3766> themselves,<WH6398> they bring forth their young,<WH3206> they end<WH7971> their labor pains.<WH2256>
Their young ones<WH1121> become strong.<WH2492> They grow up<WH7235> in the open field.<WH1250> They go forth,<WH3318> and don't<WH7725> return again.
"Who has set<WH7971> the wild donkey<WH6501> free?<WH2670> Or who has loosened<WH6605> the bonds<WH4147> of the swift donkey,<WH6171>
Whose home<WH1004> I have made<WH7760> the wilderness,<WH6160> and the salt<WH4420> land his dwelling place?<WH4908>
He scorns<WH7832> the tumult<WH1995> of the city,<WH7151> neither does he hear<WH8085> the shouting<WH8663> of the driver.<WH5065>
The range<WH3491> of the mountains<WH2022> is his pasture,<WH4829> He searches<WH1875> after<WH310> every green thing.<WH3387>
"Will the wild ox<WH7214> be content<WH14> to serve<WH5647> you?<WH3885> Or will he stay by your feeding trough?<WH18>
Can you hold<WH7194> the wild ox<WH7214> in the furrow<WH8525> with his harness?<WH5688> Or will he till<WH7702> the valleys<WH6010> after you?<WH310>
Will you trust<WH982> him,<WH3581> because his strength is great?<WH7227> Or will you leave<WH5800> to him your labor?<WH3018>
Will you confide<WH539> in him,<WH7725> that he will bring home your seed,<WH2233> and gather<WH622> the grain of your threshing floor?<WH1637>
"The wings<WH3671> of the ostrich<WH5965> wave proudly;<WH7443> but are they the feathers<WH84> and plumage<WH2624> of love?<WH5133>
For she leaves<WH5800> her eggs<WH1000> on the earth,<WH776> warms<WH2552> them in the dust,<WH6083>
and forgets<WH7911> that the foot<WH7272> may crush<WH2115> them,<WH7704> or that the wild animal<WH2416> may trample them.<WH1758>
She deals harshly<WH7188> with her young ones,<WH1121> as if they were not<WH3808> hers.<WH3018> Though her labor is in vain,<WH7385> she is without fear,<WH6343>
because God<WH433> has deprived<WH5382> her of wisdom,<WH2451> neither has he imparted<WH2505> to her understanding.<WH998>
When<WH6256> she lifts up<WH4754> herself on high,<WH4791> she scorns<WH7832> the horse<WH5483> and his rider.<WH7392>
"Have you given<WH5414> the horse<WH5483> might?<WH1369> Have you clothed<WH3847> his neck<WH6677> with a quivering mane?<WH7483>
Have you made him to leap<WH7493> as a locust?<WH697> The glory<WH1935> of his snorting<WH5170> is awesome.<WH367>
He paws<WH2658> in the valley,<WH6010> and rejoices<WH7797> in his strength.<WH3581> He goes out<WH3318> to meet<WH7125> the armed men.<WH5402>
He mocks<WH7832> at fear,<WH6343> and is not dismayed,<WH2865> neither does he turn back<WH7725> from<WH6440> the sword.<WH2719>
The quiver<WH827> rattles<WH7439> against him,<WH3851> the flashing spear<WH2595> and the javelin.<WH3591>
He eats<WH1572> up the ground<WH776> with fierceness<WH7494> and rage,<WH7267> neither does he stand still<WH539> at the sound<WH6963> of the trumpet.<WH7782>

As often as the trumpet<WH7782> sounds<WH1767> he snorts,<WH559> <WH1889> 'Aha!' <WH1889> He smells<WH7306> the battle<WH4421> afar off,<WH7350> the thunder<WH7482> of the captains,<WH8269> and the shouting.<WH8643>
"Is it by your wisdom<WH998> that the hawk<WH5322> soars,<WH82> and stretches<WH6566> her wings<WH3671> toward the south?<WH8486>
Is it at your command<WH6310> that the eagle<WH5404> mounts up,<WH1361> and makes<WH7311> his nest<WH7064> on high?<WH7311>
On the cliff<WH5553> he dwells,<WH7931> and makes his home,<WH3885> on the point<WH5553> of the cliff,<WH8127> and the stronghold.<WH4686>
From there he spies<WH2658> out the prey.<WH400> His eyes<WH5869> see<WH5027> it afar off.<WH7350>
His young ones<WH667> also suck up<WH5966> blood.<WH1818> Where the slain<WH2491> are,<WH1931> there he is."
